In the realm of physics, gravity is a fundamental force that binds us to our planet and shapes the cosmos. It's the force that keeps our feet on the ground and planets in their orbits. But what exactly is gravity? It's a force that arises from the presence of mass. Two masses attract each other with a force proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them. This concept was elegantly illustrated by Sir Isaac Newton with his law of universal gravitation. Yet, in the 20th century, Albert Einstein expanded our understanding of gravity with his theory of general relativity, revealing it as a curvature of space-time caused by the presence of mass. In essence, gravity is not just a force, but a shape-shifter of the fabric of the universe itself.

In the realm of quantum physics, the enigmatic behavior of particles defies our classical understanding. For instance, the famous double-slit experiment demonstrates the wave-particle duality. Here, light or matter pass through two slits, creating an interference pattern on a screen, as if they were waves. Yet, when observed, these particles behave as individual particles, passing through only one slit. This paradoxical phenomenon, known as wave-particle duality, underscores the intricate and fascinating world of quantum mechanics, where reality seems to bend to the observer's presence.

In the realm of quantum mechanics, a fundamental concept is the wave-particle duality. For instance, light, traditionally considered a wave, can be observed as particles known as photons. Conversely, electrons, perceived as particles, can diffract like waves, bending around obstacles in a pattern similar to light waves. This intriguing duality challenges our understanding of the natural world, forcing us to reconsider conventional notions of matter and energy. Delving deeper into this enigma, we uncover a universe that defies our intuition, where particles can exist in multiple places at the same time and interactions occur instantaneously across vast distances, bending the fabric of space-time itself. A cat, confined within a sealed box, is linked to a radioactive atom. If the atom decays, a hammer breaks a vial of poison, killing the cat. This paradoxical scenario, though seemingly absurd, underscores the counterintuitive nature of quantum physics, where particles can be in multiple places at once, and events can be influenced by measurements made later in time.
